verse: Sarah lived to be one hundred twenty-seven years old [such were the years of Sarah’s life].
She died in Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron [city nineteen miles south of Jerusalem]) in the land of Canaan. Abraham ·was very sad [mourned] and cried because of her.

After a while he got up from the side of his ·wife’s body [dead] and went to talk to the Hittites [one of the many groups that made up the population of Canaan at the time, notable in that they were not Semitic as the others were]. He said,

“I am only a ·stranger [sojourner; wanderer; resident alien] and a ·foreigner [settler; the combination of terms indicates a resident alien] here. Sell me some ·of your land [property for a burial place] so that I can bury my ·dead wife [dead].”

“·Sir [My lord], you are a ·great leader [mighty prince; or prince of God; a man of wealth and power even though he owned no land] among us. You may have the ·best [choicest] place we have to bury your dead. You may have any of our burying places that you want, and none of us will stop you from burying your ·dead wife [dead].”
Abraham rose and bowed to the people of the land, the Hittites.
He said to them, “If you truly ·want to help me [are willing for me to] bury my ·dead wife [dead] here, ·speak to [entreat] Ephron, the son of Zohar for me.
Ask him to sell me the cave of Machpelah at the edge of his field. I will pay him the full price. You can be the witnesses that I am buying it as a burial place.”
Ephron was sitting among the Hittites at the city gate [place where commercial transactions took place]. He answered Abraham [in the hearing of the Hittites],
“No, ·sir [my Lord]. [Hear me,] I will give you the ·land [field] and the cave that is in it, with these people as witnesses. Bury your ·dead wife [dead].”
Then Abraham bowed down before the ·Hittites [people of the land].
He said to Ephron ·before [in the hearing of] all the people, “·Please let me [Listen to me. I will] pay you the full price for the field. Accept my money, and I will bury my dead there.”

“·Sir [My Lord], [Listen to me,] the land is worth ·ten pounds [400 shekels] of silver, ·but I won’t argue with you over the price [what is that between you and me?]. Take the land, and bury your ·dead wife [dead].”

Abraham ·agreed [listened] and paid Ephron in front of the Hittite witnesses. He weighed out the full price, ·ten pounds [400 shekels] of silver, and they counted the weight as the traders normally did.
After this, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre. (Mamre was later called Hebron in the land of Canaan.)
So Abraham bought the field and the cave in it from the Hittites to use as a burying place.
